transcript:
Hi my name is Jake Patterson and this is my submission for session 11 assignment

Define:
The core question is whether the buyback creates more value than alternative uses of the same $90B—specifically a special dividend, debt reduction, an AI/VR acquisition, or incremental R&D. Key constraints are Apple's liquidity and its current capital structure.

Discover:
I identified the finance tools I need: EPS mechanics, leverage effects, ROIC vs. WACC for investment decisions, and agency and signaling considerations. The key is comparing value creation to value transfer across stakeholders.

Represent:
I built a small model with transparent inputs—share price, share count, net income, debt, ROIC assumptions—and six scenarios: baseline, buyback, dividend, debt paydown, and two reinvestment cases. Each scenario outputs EPS and Debt/Market Cap so I can see both return and risk effects.

Implement:
In Python, each scenario is its own function.

The buyback reduces shares outstanding and recomputes EPS.

Debt paydown adds interest savings to net income.

Acquisition and R&D scenarios add earnings based on assumed ROIC.
The same structure lets me change any assumption and instantly update all outputs.

Validate:
I check that cash used never exceeds $90B and confirm expected patterns: buybacks increase EPS mechanically, debt paydown lowers leverage, and high-ROIC investments outperform buybacks when ROIC is above the cost of capital.

Evolve:
Using the scenario toggles, I compare which stakeholders win under each option: buybacks help short-term holders and option owners; reinvestment benefits long-term equity; debt paydown favors bondholders and reduces risk. The EPS chart makes these trade-offs visible.

Reflect:If Apple has credible projects with ROIC above WACC, reinvestment creates the most sustainable value. If not, a smaller, disciplined buyback combined with some debt reduction is the better balance.
